title: Had my first ever experience with group psychodrama today. It was a disaster. Went through my first panic attack in over a decade.
content:
I’ve been in treatment for my eating disorder since July. I’ve really enjoyed the program and this is the longest and best I’ve ever been in recovery. Last week we were introduced to the new psychodrama therapist. I have zero experience with it, and quite frankly roleplaying negative experiences of my life (not even the traumatic ones) in a group setting just does not appeal to me.

This was our first actual group and from the very beginning I knew I was in for a shitshow. The therapist starts off by saying “I want you to think of a time when you were truamatized”. The first thing I thought of was my sexual assault in the psych ward by another patient while I was in a medication induced psychosis.

Now look, one could argue that I could’ve just chosen a little T trauma instead, but for whatever reason I went with the worst moment of my life. Either way though if you ask me about trauma and that’s where my brain goes, so immediately all of the memories started surfacing again. 5 minutes into the group and I’m already distressed.

She made us one by one tell her about our traumas and most of the clients voiced their discomfort, but she seemed very dismissive about it. When I told mine, she asked “So that was traumatizing for you?” Uh… no shit?

Our next assignment was to close our eyes and envision what we were feeling in that moment, essentially having us relive our traumas. For obvious reasons I did not do this.

After that she passed out paper and markers and had us draw our emotions. Fine, whatever.

She had us get up and talk to the drawings like they were the source of the trauma (i.e. a family member, an abuser, etc.). The first girl that went was no issue.

Here’s where it gets worse.

The next person that went had trauma revolving around a family member. I won’t give details obviously, but as he progressed the therapist started mirroring him and essentially saying what she thought he was feeling internally. 

There was a point where she just yelled something that was clearly very triggering for him and he broke immediately. He started sobbing and yelling the things he would’ve said to this family member and it was incredibly distressing to watch and made a ton of repressed memories of my own familial trauma resurface.

One of my biggest triggers is yelling, even if it’s not directed at me. The second the yelling started I felt like I became detached from my body, like none of this was actually real. I’ve never felt like that before and it was genuinely terrifying. Obviously I do not blame the client for one second, but for the first time since I started treatment, I got up and left group.

The second I closed the door to the group room I started sobbing and hyperventilating. I’ll be real, it takes a lot to break me so when the clinical director saw me she immediately knew it was bad. She went and grabbed my individual therapist who basically had to sit there and help me ground myself until I could speak again.

When I explained to him what happened during group he told me that essentially I derealized. I have friends who experience it, but this is all new to me.

I’ve been texting back and forth with the other clients and every single one said they felt incredibly uncomfortable with the whole process.

So yeah, not a fan of psychodrama. :)

I’ve been stuck in the middle of a ‘rapid rising’ river, almost not making it back to my group. I’ve seen my entire town flood. When I was a kid I broke my jaw really bad. 
Since I was a child, I’ve had nightmares. I’d wake up screaming and crying for my mom. For the past year (at least) I’ve been having what I call stress dreams EVERY night. It’s to the point that I’m tired all the time but I don’t want to sleep because I know I’ll stress more and wake up more tired. I did get a little bit of a break the night of my brothers wedding. I had officiated and made another speech. By the end of the day, I crashed hard. No dreams. The next night it went back to normal. 
Now, my dreams aren’t always about the actual events of my trauma. I often have dreams of the world ending and the sky getting red. The darker the red, the closer to the end of the world other dreams, we are in the woods, running from something. Other times, the world is flooding and my mom and I cannot contact anyone. When we try to leave, we get blocked by the police because everything up ahead is already under water. I’ve dreamt that I’m on a boat in the middle of the ocean in the night and it wrecks. I would look under me in the water and a shark was right there, mouth open. I’d have dreams about needing another surgery. I don’t wake up screaming but my dreams leave me very distressed when I do wake up. I am anxious, sad, mad, stressed, and overwhelmed when I wake up and those feelings last all day. Last nights dream was particularly intense. 

‘My brother and his wife were giving birth. It was a home birth in their bathtub. My mom and I are sitting on the couch in the living room, waiting for the news. My brother and sil come out with one baby. A boy. They say they had twins. I ask where the other one is and brother said ‘in the bathroom’. I asked if I could go in and see the baby and he said ‘you can go in’. So I do and I see a pale baby with the umbilical cord still attached, floating face down in the tub. I grab the baby and while pulling it out of the water, I noticed that it is cold and stiff. It’s a girl. I try to do CPR and holler out to call an ambulance then I wake up.’ I cried when I woke up. 
Im exhausted all the time and I just want simple happy dreams or none at all. Im so sorry for the lengthy post I just don’t know what else to do. The I’ve tried so many medications and they haven’t worked. Anyways, no more pity party and back to the question.
When I describe these dreams, I don’t know what to call them. Whether they are bad dreams or nightmares or stress dreams or what have you. Any advice is much appreciated and if anyone has any ideas on how to manage my feelings I will happily ready everything! Thanks in advance and good night!

title: feeling like a zombie all day and a manic impulsive mess all night. desperately seeking advice
content:
ok this is like totally tmi and i’ve never shared anything like this before, especially not online, but about two months ago, on the night of my son’s first birthday, i was raped anally by someone very very close to me. since then, i can’t seem to process anything. i have similar trauma from my childhood that i can think through in detail and map out on a mental timeline. but with this particular event, my brain will not let me think about it. every time i try to think about the events leading up to it, during it, or even weeks after it, i feel like my brain just shuts down and i can’t properly remember anything. i’m in a near constant state of dissociation. 

 i have a one year old son and i’m honestly kind of glad my brain is responding like this because it allows me to behave relatively normally and take care of my child like a regular mother. in my high school years i behaved incredibly recklessly due to past trauma and landed myself in rehabs and mental institutions more times than i’d like to admit. obviously i’m a very different person now and would never act on my impulsive thoughts considering i have a baby in the picture. however, after my son goes to sleep it’s like all hell breaks lose. all of a sudden i feel like i can’t sleep despite being EXHAUSTED the entire day. no matter how hard i try i just can’t get myself to lay down. my brain floods with thoughts of self harm, suicide and other risky behaviors. and i can’t shut it off no matter what i do. i feel so helpless. the whole night i’m trying to keep calm and make it to morning. pacing back and forth or watching tv to distract myself. God forbid the show has a joke about anal though or i literally start tweaking the fuck out lol i know that sounds stupid but i genuinely get panic attacks from jokes like that even if it has nothing to do with rape. which sucks cause we live in a culture where anal is a very normal thing so jokes like that are in basically everything. i usually only can get myself to go to sleep at around 5 am after my fiancé comes home (he works night shift) which is absolutely not sustainable as my son has a normal sleep schedule (asleep by 9 pm). and when i do finally get to sleep, it’s just brutal gruesome nightmares. i never ever feel rested. most days i find myself sleeping in past noon, usually around 2 or 3, while my fiancé takes care of our son. i feel so guilty. this is killing me and it’s absolutely not sustainable. 

 when i do wake up, i genuinely feel like a zombie. no amount of sleep ever feels like enough. 

 taking care of my son comes naturally to me so that’s not an issue. i usually just play with him all day and we go for walks and to the park and everything is fine. i smile and play and talk to him and it reminds me of a time where i felt happier and wasn’t just faking my way through life. the whole time i’m barely hanging on. but like i don’t even feel sad. i just feel empty and out of it. so exhausted and just completely beat down. nothing feels okay anymore. i’m totally dissociated during the day and completely hyper vigilant at night. it’s literally driving me crazy. 

 i seriously don’t know how to fix this. i can’t take medication to sleep cause i need to not be knocked out if my baby starts crying in the middle of the night and needs me (which he frequently does). obviously can’t smoke weed or anything. i have no one to talk to either. the only two people who know are my fiancé (who kind of acts weird about it and is also very close to the man who assaulted me so it’s kind of an odd situation where he doesn’t want to fully admit something bad happened) and my ex best friend. when i told her she said that i absolutely have to go to the police and when i refused, she ended the friendship and called me a bitch lmao. i’m catholic and the only thing that’s sort of helps and brings me some sort of peace is going to church. but it’s not a cure or anything. i still live with my parents (i’m only 19) and they have no idea. it’s so disturbing watching everyone act like everything’s normal while simultaneously harboring this dark secret that could blow up my whole life and the lives of so many other people, while also being the victim of it all. i almost feel angry at the whole world for not realizing something is wrong. but also i would never ever want anyone to find out. anyways i’m considering going back to therapy but i lowkey don’t have a drivers license and my fiancé takes the car to work everyday so not sure what to do. if u have any advice PLEASE  share. i’m so desperate and willing to listen

title: don’t feel valid in my trauma
content:
21f have never posted on here before. 
My best friend 19f was shot in a mass shooting in July at a birthday party. 3 including her were injured, 4 died that night. 
I found out in the morning and didn’t know how to react except for extreme depression. I stayed with her in the hospital daily and helped her as much as I could physically until she was ready to talk about things mentally.  
A few nights ago she asked me to listen to some calls that got sent to her on accident from that night. I said yes because I have always been there for her why would I not? 
Listening to the calls set me right back to how I felt the days following the shooting. It’s all I can think about. Even when I’m reading, on TikTok talking on the phone literally something completely unrelated to the event. When I cry I remember the voices of the kids on the call at the party crying. When I walk around work it’s all I can hear in my head just playing on a loop. It’s fully consumed my brain and thinking process. 

I was not at the party. I feel so phony for even feeling like my anxieties and symptoms are ptsd related because I wasn’t there. I feel like a poser. Like I shouldn’t be in any pain because I wasn’t there. I feel like this imposter syndrome has made me neglect getting the help I need. 

Does anyone else have a similar story or experience?

title: I’m unable speak loudly or yell, I’m quiet like a ninja.
content: I grew up in an alcoholic household. It was like a minefield. You never knew what would trigger an explosion from my dad and he’d be violent. When I was 6 my dad was supposed to be watching us while my mom was out but he passed out drunk on the couch. I was watching tv with the volume low and my brother walked up behind me and changed the channel. I blew up and yelled at him which woke my dad. He beat me and my brother. My face was so bad I went to stay with my grandma so no one would see. My grandma sent my uncle to threaten my dad’s life if he ever touched me again. He didn’t but I was still terrified. I’m turning 59 soon. I walk so quietly that I always creep up on people and scare them. I’m unable to raise my voice. I have never yelled at anyone since. Trying to sounds ridiculous, it’s so forced. My brain just won’t allow it. I just needed to say it, to get it out. People say I’m quiet and stealthy like a ninja. I seldom feel like a ninja.

content:

title: I don’t know if this is valid medical trauma or not
content:
I’m just so confused on whenever these moments are valid, or even actually sexual assault cause my therapist refuses to confirm if they are or not. I have medical ptsd from multiple instances from my life. But these few instances really have been on my mind for months after I finally resurfaced the memories. 
My pediatrician who was otherwise nice and helpful would always do genital exams on me all the way up into my teen years. She would even touch me down there with my mom in the room, she never asked for my consent and always asked my mom but never me. I always felt violated every time I left. There’s this other one that’s been eating at me and it’s when I developed really bad neck and back pain as a teenager. My chiropractor would have me get undressed into just a gown and my bra and panties. Sometimes without my bra, and he’d have me take my gown off I believe sometimes. I know chiropractors get up and close and personal but he’d get ontop of me, during this for back and hip adjustments. There wasn’t even female nurses or staff in the room I was always alone. I never even questioned it until now, because I was taught to never question doctors. I thought it was a routine thing since he technically was a doctor.

title: trouble staying asleep with ptsd
content:
so i’ve had ptsd for about 4/5 years now, due to sexual abuse. i had a nightmare maybe a year in that triggered a rush of memories and i’ve had insomnia ever since. 
there was a period where i would avoid sleep due to the constant vivid nightmares but now that i work and go to school, it’s best if i try to get what sleep i can.
i don’t really have trouble going to sleep, my eyes usually get super heavy or i get a terrible headache (i do have chronic headaches now) so i just sleep for as long i can.
the only time i sleep straight through the night or wake up only once is when i sleep with my boyfriend. for background, we’ve done a sort of intimacy work w/ massages and deep breathing so that my body/ mind could identify him as someone safe.
at home however, if someone so much as touches my door handle my eyes shoot open and my naps can never be longer than an hour-30 minutes.
i also smoke indica pretty often, as it usually helps with anxiety in the day time. and i’ve tried skullcap tincture, which is a sedative.

i was just wondering if anyone could help me understand it better? like maybe why i can’t relax enough to stay asleep or work i can do w/myself so that i know that i’m safe. or just if anyone relates, that’s helpful too!

title: Ptsd symptom question
content:
Hi everyone.
I have a variety of complex traumas, and I was told my my mental health practice that I have ptsd.
The most obvious symptom for me was the hyperealistic dreams, with intense emotion. Something simple like a fireplace, filled with dread and so much horror.. etc.
These dreams recur, multiple times a night, for up to 3 weeks. I remember multiple dreams from one night too.
Then id wake up panicked, heart racing and my overall day would be affected with me being irritable, stressed, panicked.

I was recently thinking for about, indirect symptoms.

Specifically, discomfort in my torso, not like pain, it's a weird feeling, I'm unsure what it is. It will get worse, il gag a lot and then il feel an but better.
And i when I close my eyes, I see vivid images with lots of emotion.
Just the other day, I was parked up near the beach, enjoying the night view of the sea front.
Feeling good. I closed my eyes, and saw a weird thing, with a pulsing and bulging lump, I was curious and felt compelled. I watched as it continued to pulsate and bulge from this sphere of maybe sinew?
I was then unable to open my eyes, I felt like I couldn't even try. Like a trance?
I felt overshadowed with emotion, and this fleshy sphere morphed it's shape over and over until I opened my eyes and cried.

If anyone can talk to me about those other symptoms, because I'm so alone and want answers.

Ps. I am not usually emotional at all, I'm diagnosed with autism and alexithymia. I go years without crying, or even feeling like I need to cry.

Thanks

title: How do you deal with survivor's guilt and intense loneliness?
content: I worked in direct care healthcare during the pandemic and for a significant amount of time "after."  I have been away from healthcare now for the last year.  I lost my job because my physical health had begun to deteriorate to the point where I eventually needed to start using a wheelchair for my own safety due to repeated falls.  I've been doing therapy and was diagnosed in 2021 with PTSD.  Lately I have been really struggling with survivor's guilt and intense loneliness.  It feels like no one in the world knows what it was like and quite frankly, I feel guilty for surviving when so many people didn't.  I worked multiple covid units in a nursing home where the situation was wildly mismanaged resulting in many deaths.  When I left the nursing home I went to one of the local hospitals but ended up working on their gen med/covid floor.  I was often the only cna to 30+ people.  It was impossible to do enough.  I tried.  I tried so hard.  It wasn't quite so bad in the hospital because there were more resources and comfort to be provided to the patients but in the nursing home it was- something else entirely.  Anyways, I guess that's a little bit of backstory.  Just wondering if anybody has any gems of wisdom cuz this whole existing thing is getting tough.

title: Anyone else deal with involuntary orgasms?
content:
Hi, I'm 24 AFAB enby and I haven't been officially diagnosed with ptsd, but I originally posted about this in r/bpd and someone suggested i post here as well.

I have been dealing with these involuntary orgasms (I'll abbreviate to IO) since I was 21. At the time, I was misdiagnosed with bipolar disorder and thought the IO was related to the hypersexuality common in manic episodes.

But the IO happened with and without my "manic" symptoms, and I was eventually rediagnosed with bpd. 

The IOs have become very intense again this week, and I just made the connection that it started again after I had a creepy incident where I thought someone may have been trying to SA me (nothing happened tho)

Since the incident I've been ruminating about my past SA and I've been having sexual nightmares again, along with increased irritability and sensory issues, and of course the IO.

To be clear the IO comes on suddenly with NO external or internal stimulation. I can be walking, laying down, having a random conversation, etc. Sometimes it seems triggered by thinking about sexual things, but often it just comes out of nowhere.

Does anyone else relate or have any advice? 

Also I plan to talk to my new therapist about all of this, but the appointment isn't until Friday ToT

title: How to build a routine in the ruins of the aftermath?
content: I’m trying to become “human” again and it’s hard. I lack motivation to do small things but have high ambitions so it leaves me feeling useless. This can be anything from keeping a job where conflict arises, making important calls, and even basic hygiene. I have a great supportive family and a support system that ranges from my HS teachers and professors I meet in undergrad and in my graduate studies, Friends from K-12, a few friends from Uni my brain doesn’t tie to my trauma, and even new people Im meeting as I build my career and my own business.  I’m having a rough time starting a daily routine, building motivation for task,  and sticking to plans. Does anyone have any tips or tricks they use for themselves to keep moving forward rather than running backwards when it’s time to really push yourself and your dreams? I feel like if I really give this a chance I will look back on these moments and turn than energy into helping others like myself or not become like how I am now, which is why I started the business. I know this all stems from me seeing myself as an unlovable and undeserving victim but I know if I can do things that push me towards goals or even just eat 3 meals a day, life may start to have a lot more light.

title: Getting out of the flight response
content: I regularly end up in the flight response, usually in the days after I have had an emotional flashback. Unfortunately I put myself in potentially dangerous situations, by running away somewhere dark/unsafe or standing on the end of bridges. I just want to escape. title: Recently I've begun to laugh at my trauma.
content:
I guess it's a way to cope - having the completely opposite reaction I used to have. 

CPT therapy has helped a TON recently but now whenever I get triggered I feel like laughing. Not because it's funny but because it's the only thing to keep me straight and center - without flying off the rails.

Does anyone else do this. I guess it's something to be positive about.

title: Just another post frustrated with people casually using "traumatized" and "PTSD"

title: Is it normal/reasonable to need special seating if you’re struggling with PTSD/hypervigilance/survival mode? Am I overreacting?
content:
I just joined a new support group for people with special needs last month, but I hate going and I'm at my wits end with it already cause I can never find a quiet, truly secluded place to sit and work. 99% of the building is a shitty cafeteria set up where the tables and chairs are arranged in a spiral pattern with zero space or privacy. 

I hate almost everyone here and I get extremely triggered if people walk or stand near or behind me, stand in front of me too close etc, and almost all of them are annoying neurotypicals (it's not just a place for people with mental disabilities) that love yapping to me when they know I have my headphones in.

(I'm also autistic so I have to have some type of music on at all times to stay sane and block them out)

There's literally nowhere to sit that's not gonna trigger me except for this tiny glass pod that I'm in right now, but the door is see through so even that doesn't feel comfortable/safe if I see someone standing near it.

I feel like a Karen for having so many needs and idk how much of this is autism and how much is actually a trauma response. 

I keep trying to push myself out of my comfort zone and embrace compromise, but when I actually get here I end up getting triggered and hating everyone/wanting to go home ASAP. I feel like I can't even be productive or enjoy my time here, no one understands me and I can't relate to anyone.

My ideal seating arrangement would be somewhere that I can sit in a corner by myself with my back/sides facing the wall and desk, a large amount of space between my desk and whoever's surrounding me OUTSIDE of my bubble, working by myself without being interrupted or triggered all the time, some type of door or barrier between me and the other person that doesn't leave any part of me open.

Am I seething for no reason or is it normal to feel super uncomfortable/unsafe around everyone just for existing near me?? I don't know what to do and every time I try to ask for some type of accommodation I hit a dead end or someone else lies about their needs so they can take advantage of what I'm asking for....

I feel like I'm destined to die alone and friendless cause I'll never be able to put on a happy face and pretend to not wanna rip my skin off if I'm sitting with strangers. Everyone probably already thinks I'm an asshole cause I'm an introvert and rarely ever smile...

Will everything be ok or is it already over for me? I'm almost 28. Is it too late for me to go from being an agoraphobic shut in to a social butterfly that doesn't let shit get to them this easily? I just feel so hopeless and lonely right now...

title: In my (30F) first serious relationship. Struggling with trust and mood swings. Need advice/possibly resource recommendations
content:
I have PTSD from recurring violent experiences from someone close to me as a child. Because of the trust issues stemming from my PTSD, I'm quite delayed when it comes to romantic relationships. Last month, however, I met a girl and we've really hit it off. We've been on multiple dates, text constantly, and she's even spent a few nights at my apartment.

I like this girl a lot. She is so kind, patient, and understanding, and talking and spending time with her is really fun. I feel like I have so much more energy after spending time with her, and like I can feel my life getting better in real time. Not to mention, she's really cute. I should be euphoric, right?

Instead, I'm constantly worrying. Can I trust this person? Will she try to control me? If I don't do what she wants, will she hurt me? Despite the fact that she hasn't shown the slightest bit of violence or controlling behavior towards me, these are the thoughts that plague me whenever we're apart and sometimes even when we're together. I can be enjoying an evening with her, having a good time, and then suddenly, I'll feel trapped and overwhelmed and like I just want her to leave. Fortunately, she's very understanding. Though I haven't given her the gory details of my trauma, she knows I have PTSD and I've given her a basic overview of how it affects my relationships (namely, how it makes me freak out and think people who want to get close to me are bound to hurt/kill me). She's said that if I ever need it, we can just drop everything and do separate things for a few hours or even that she can just go for a walk so I have some private space to calm myself down.

I'm just really frustrated at how these feelings make me feel like shit even when she's so wonderful, and especially how they seem to dull the positive emotions I should have. I'd like to ask how you all coped with the difficulties presented by PTSD in your romantic relationships. Did you just push through them until you'd finally developed trust with the other person? Were there strategies you used to quiet the negative, fearful voices that constantly intruded on the relationship? I'd also love if you all could share any resources that were helpful to you, like books, worksheets, videos, etc.  

Thank you!

(BTW, I have also recently started seeing a therapist again, in case that's relevant)

title: Fear of leaving family to go on university fieldwork abroad
content: I (19F) am currently studying at university in my first year on a course I'm really enjoying- I love the content, the people I'm with are mostly lovely, I passed the first 2 modules, but part of my course is a compulsory trip abroad (going to Africa from the UK). When I applied to the course I thought I'd be excited and it would be a great opportunity, but now the reality of a month away from my family where I won't be able to regularly contact them or know how they're doing is setting in and I'm terrified. I've got PTSD from a traumatic bereavement and part of growing up with that has made me think that me being absent from my families' lives will result in them dying and I won't be there to help or comfort or try to fix it and it'll be my fault for going away. I've tried so many different therapists and it's been 8 years since the event that caused this, but I'm not sure if this is something I can get over? I don't want to have to quit my course, but I'm so so scared of if I'm going to have a breakdown and flashbacks when I'm there which I haven't suffered with for about 6 months. I've talked to my parents and they've assured me they won't die, and even if something happened it wouldn't be my fault, but it doesn't make my brain stop telling me these things. Does anyone have any advice?

title: Mounting minority stressors compounding PTSD - Resources seem limited if non-existent
content:
From my last post, thank you everyone who responded and all the support. I didn't go into details because all of this has just been a lot and I'm not sure if anyone here will understand. Going to go out on a limb and see if anyone happens to have any specific advice for my situation. 




TW: Violence and S/A mentions, minority stressors



My spouse was threatened at work with corrective rape and assault because she is married to me, a transgender man. On top of very recent surgery for her that triggered memories of my mother's unfortunate medical ailments and times during my childhood, followed by people at work seeing me in distress during that time they started acting in such a way to me because of my minority status (they told me straight up). Add that my workplace has told me to be patient, my union has told me to be patient, and one supervisor straight up laughed at me over it all, I am struggling. 

Has anything happened TO ME? Nope, not a damn thing lately. But here I am, out of work for now because going there sends me into a spiral. Staying home feels safe, but every day my spouse goes into work I am met with going into a spiral again just a lot less. Insurance sees it as a work issue, not covered by them. WCB sees my medical file and sees I'm trans, says that there is no way to prove my stress is only work related, no coverage from them. Police see it all as an interpersonal conflict, no help from them. Union sees it as "we have to listen to all sides" issue, no help from them. Employer keeps asking if I just want to quit already (they sent me paperwork to give for unemployment filings encouraging me to given my notice), no help from them. Gone through a number of therapists, some stating beyond scope, others trying but so limited on what can be done about the situation, no help from them. Friends of ours just don't know how to help, typically just start weeping, or have been so burnt out by it all so no help from them. Spouse is a mess some days, but dissociates easily. Field we are in is best paying, best benefits, without it our life saving medications are not available. Law firms (many contacted) are limited because of the nature of law needed AND most have a conflict of interest with the union or employer having represented one or the other, and in my case it would be me going against both. 

I am at a loss for what to do with myself in terms of employment, in terms of mental health care during this time. I'm in resilience training and I can say that other's in similar situations as me are struggling to find worth from the whole thing because what can we realistically get out of it? I am at such a loss of what to do. I'm doing exposure therapy to actively try to go back to something hostile but with mounting hatred for folks of my minority status in the western world, this hostility is growing. I am hurting and struggling with threats when folks find out and when I am in public spaces with visibly queer people. I can hide myself well enough but I get "transvestigated" because of scar tissue I happen to have. I can function daily well enough that I don't warrant disability, but when I go into workplaces that find out (and do to legal things with background checks it's not hard to figure out) I am met with hostility. What the hell do I do? What therapy can help me through this? Shitty life syndrome makes CBT feel like a stupid gaslighting chore of accepting that life sucks and suck it up buttercup, enjoy your harassment. I know that is not what it is but when the therapist says, there is nothing I can do to help you, I don't think anyone can. What do you fucking do? I feel failed by life because of populist politics using me as a scape goat. 

I breathe, I exercise, I eat well, I do physio, I do somatic exercises, I do journalling, I do therapy, I spend time with friends, I engage in hobbies, I limit screen time, I wash myself up and take care of myself. I don't drink and I don't do recreational drugs. I still feel dread, panic, and then have flashes of images of people harming my loved ones because I'M trans. I promptly dissociate and I dissociate a lot. What more can I do? I took medications but the side effects after six months were great and I stopped showering and no longer enjoyed my hobbies at all. I have tried others with no luck, and I don't want medication anymore when things are so situational based. 

This isn't hopeless and I find joy in little things involving my spouse, involving friends, in the joys in life. There is so much joy in life. Employment brings me no joy and it is painful, I've already lost 3 jobs because of my trans status. 

I have attempted radical acceptance of this situation I cannot control but I am left feeling a level of rancor which impacts my ability to enjoy life. I don't want to accept that people like myself have to accept harassment and persecution. I have been active in social movements and it gives me some purpose but I find that they are being met with so much hatred that I don't know how many more violent assaults I can endure witnessing. What the hell do I even do? 

Does anyone know resources for those trapped in violent areas, or just like... Resources that can actually ease this? I hate this and it feels like the more happy I am, the more bitter certain individuals become towards me. Even with cisgender (the opposite of transgender, just a non-transgender person) folks I know have told me how it isn't fair that I can access therapy and they can't. Or it isn't fair I'm married and found someone and they can't as a non-trans person. It isn't fair that I can still laugh and smile when I play with my pets, etc. and how lucky I am I'm not working right now and "milking it." It isn't fair that I have stable housing and they don't. This is such a joke to me and I find it weird that folks like this exist that would say these things. 

A ramble to say the least, but I just hope there are resources out there online that is available internationally to people (I am not based in the US).

title: This disorder is so embarrassing
content:
Obligatory "I don't mean to suggest that you *should* be ashamed of yourself if you have PTSD," I was just feeling embarrassed about some of the symptoms and wanted to post about it here. 

I'm embarrassed that I can't fall asleep without holding a comfort blanket. 

I'm embarrassed that I'll shout in my sleep and wake other people up when I'm having weird dreams. 

I'm embarrassed without how much my hands shake (enough that other people have commented on it). 

I'm embarrassed with how tired and jumpy I am all the time. 

I'm embarrassed every time I flinch/jump/cry in public. 

I'm embarrassed every time people talk about the thing that happened to me and I ask them to stop, and doubly so every time they tell me to get over it and that I'm being dramatic. 

I'm embarrassed with how I can't remember anything except this one specific thing.  

I'm embarrassed that the same thing happened to tons of other people I know and they didn't get PTSD but somehow I did. 

I'm embarrassed to say the name of the diagnosis and people look at me and say "You're a teenaged girl, you're too young for it." 

I'm embarrassed that I need to ask for so much help and I'm still not fully better.

title: Just Looking For Catharsis
content:
It has been twenty years since my first trauma and 15 since my last, and it makes me feel old saying that.  I can't say if my history bogs me down physically or if chronic fatigue is a manifestation of being bogged down emotionally.  The last five years have been internationally tough and I feel like I just wear it all, I am weathered.  I turned towards the news in 2019 and haven't been able to sever the habit.  I have trouble devesting emotionally from tragedies in the world because it makes me feel like my experiences are just the tip of such a sad and horrific iceberg.  I feel so much anger that there can be so many people living with trauma and still the tides haven't turned, and people and societies continue making the same mistakes.  I feel like there is a strong and legitimate sadness in the world that has become an excuse to drink more than I should (I also write letters to governments but I imagine they must laugh at my words, so it is just one more negative coping strategy).  Sometimes I think it all hits me more intensely than others around me because of my history, or maybe I am still in overdrive and the stress exceeds my coping capacity.  
  
I realize at this age how long I have been coasting on feelings that I made it, I survived.   
It doesn't matter.  I let the adversity seep back in as an excuse while neglecting to do everyday things to feed my wellness.  
  
So, after self-contemplating for almost an hour while writing this, I realize I have become complacent in my recovery and let myself slide from previous peaks under the guise that overall stability is as good as anything.  So my newest PTSD lesson to share is that recovery is an *active* process, forever, I imagine.  
  
Thanks for being there.

title: Nervous breakdown after an emotional abuse episode: normal?
content:
I recently had a nervous breakdown (basically my body reacted with extreme stress: extreme bodywide pain, daily migraines, extreme stress-induced brain fog, anxiety attacks, heart palpitations, elevated heart rate, weight loss, severe fatigue my hair's starting to fall out, etc) for the past few weeks after the most recent abusive episode.

There was no physical violence, but he was shouting/yelling at me, expressing anger by pounding his fists, throwing/slamming things around, keeping me awake for hours arguring in circles, and threatening to tear the whole apartment up. He had this out-of-control scary look in his eyes, and is just so rageful and volatile over extremely minor things.

This is not the first episode he's had (he's had emotional/verbal abuse episodes every 1-2 months on average), but for some reason, it's the one that's stressed me out the most. He's never harmed/hit me, but he's done a lot of verbal/emotional abuse and breaks things/throws stuff around when he's angry. I was also in the middle of final exams for my graduate program, so I was already under a lot of stress. My mind and body have just been in a state of extreme shutdown and not functioning very well.

I've dealt with the abusive episodes better in the past, for some reason this one really scared me. We are taking a break now due to my nervous breakdown and I am considering ending the relationship, but I want more time to clear my head and work things out.

Is it abnormal to react this way? I feel like I'm overreacting/being too sensitive. I'm not sure why my body is reacting this way. Perhaps it could be triggering some past history I have with traumatic events (including sexual assault/rape/strangulation in the past).

It’s just embarrassing so I brush it off as a nightmare I don’t remember (which isn’t a lie)

title: PTSD - Childhood Bullying
content:
As a child, I experienced heavy and consistent bullying from about 4th grade to 8th grade, mainly on the school bus. Up to and including being physically assaulted, stabbed with pushpins and burned with a lighter. The school never took it seriously, punished me with suspensions for the same length they would the other students involved (not sure how that makes sense). No investigations and no greater involvement from the school. Parents didn’t have the money at the time to pursue it in a court of law as well. 

I went to therapy for my PTSD during college and managed it well for a few years. I was able to quell my anger and outbursts from specific triggers, but i’ve seen it slowly start to creep back into my life over the past few years (i’m now 27 years old).

Has anyone ever returned to therapy after initially thinking they have gotten themself to a comfortable spot?

TL:DR - Bullied heavily as a kid, went to therapy in my early 20’s for PTSD, now it’s rearing its head again in my work and personal life.

title: I need advice after a diagnosis of ptsd because of a "small" trauma
content:
Hello,

It's my first post here (M20). I don't know what drove to write this. I guess it was the fact that I feel no one understands. Ever. 

I was recently diagnosed with ptsd following a series of events that happened in the last years. I never thought it could lead to ptsd, because I was so used to the pain I was in all the time. I'll try to keep it short (tw: self-harm, suicide)

1. When I was 14 I started to harm myself.  My dad was emotionally abusing my mom, but we were forced to show off a fake smile everyday. He was never abusive to me though (this is important for the bigger picture). So I started to cope by hurting myself. This went on for 4 years during which no one figured out. I only stopped once I realised in therapy how unhealthy that is for me.

2. My sister tried to end her life at 13, three years ago. It was out of the blue. I had my first severe panic attack that day and things were never the same. I was left with flashbacks, recurrent panic attack, I started abusing alcohol and cigarettes. I was also recurrently losing contact with reality for brief periods of time. The pain of the memory was too great. 

3. Last month my gf passed out in college. She has multiple health issues, two of which are pretty serious (an autoimmune disorder and recurrent bouts of urticatia, the reason she passed out and ended up in the ER). You see, this seems pretty little, but it triggered something inside me. I can't say why, but it made me go back to my panic attack, anxiety, I am in constant stress that something will happen again, I get flashbacks and intrusive thoughs, I am very distrustful of people. It's like I'm waiting for something to happen again. 

Considering this, my therapist recognised ptsd. I was surprised because none of the above happened TO ME. But something did happen to me, because I'm not the same and I haven't been in a while. I have most of the textbook symptoms, except I only learnt recently they are ptsd symptoms. Now I don't know what to do with this information

Edit: I hope I didn't violate any of the rules of the community

title: How do I find work or support myself??

title: How Do You Handle Nightmares?
content:
(TW: S-side, Dr*GS, Domestic V.)

Before stating this, I want to say I go to therapy and I try to stay on top of triggers and noticing when I'm going to start shutting down. By the end of this it will make sense why I'm here.

So, my first memory was at the age of 3 or 4 (parents can't verify what age) and it's a heavy one. During an argument between my parents, my dad pushed my mom. Since he had sworn to never do that (and he suffered from untreated illness and loved drugs) his first response was to grab a steak knife, drive it into his wrist, and pull up. I vividly remember the skin separating as the blood spurted on our off-white colored fridge. My brother was less than a year old at the time, so I grabbed the baby carrier he was in and went running for help at my grandparents who lived just down the hill. From there on is mostly a blur. I remember sitting at the hospital with my mom and brother, both of them crying uncontrollably as little me tried to comfort them. He survived that attempt, luckily. But it was far from over.

Over the next 20 years of my life I saw him die, attempt, or come close to attempting 8 other times. 4 of those were the same method as before, the one that stuck with me the most being when he paced around outside of my grandparents' house for some time before using his pocket knife while leaning up against my grandma's bus. Another that always comes up is when he took a family member's pistol and put it in his mouth with full intent. My sister was just a toddler then and I made sure her and my brother were inside without much of a clue that Dad was about to do something irreversible. My grandfather managed to get the gun away from him just in time. He was in martial arts, so disarming someone came naturally. But that's not the end to it all either.

On three different occasions I witnessed him overdose and begin to cross over. The first was when I was 5. After an argument with my mom he decided to smoke something off of foil (I was born in 96, so this was before fentanyl, he was doing heroin) afterwards he slumped down in the couch as his eyes rolled back, nothing I wasn't already used to. But this time he stopped breathing altogether, and began to turn blue. I was oddly calm about the situation, telling my mom "dad'll be okay" or something along those lines. I thought he was just really high. But that image is burned into my head. Like I said, there's many more of these memories that I won't discuss here, as these are the biggest ones.

Fast forward to 2023. After seeing him relapse 8 years prior, I knew the day would come. One day after work I had the urge to get taco bell. He forced my mom and siblings out of the house so he was all alone, with me checking in him nearly every day, staying as long as I could stomach the company he kept. This day I didn't see any cars there. For a split second I debated whether to check on him or go get us Tacos and check on the way back. When I went to the door, I heard light movement, but got no answer at the door. My instincts from childhood kicked in, so I kicked in the door to find my father turning a shade of blue and growing cold fast. I immediately called the emergency services and frantically paced back and forth, waiting for help to arrive (if I knew CPR I would have tried, but I didn't want to make things worse). Medics and police arrived, tried narcan, and when it didn't work, rushed him to the hospital. It set me back what felt like years on my healing journey, and threw my whole life off. He survived but he hasn't been the same since. It still hurts my heart, but I don't speak on it much.

Since then the nightmares are more frequent again, with the most recent being today. After finally falling asleep I had a crazy dream where close to the end, that pistol attempt was successful. The image was so vivid I don't know if I can go back to sleep. I guess all I'm really writing here for is some support and advice. Like what do you do when it becomes impossible to sleep without seeing things? I usually take trazadone to sleep when this happens, but lately it results in my brain doubling down on said nightmares. How do you navigate these kinds of things? For the most part I feel I've reached a point of high functionality but these nightmares put me in a headspace that physically feels weird.

title: Why is it SO hard to talk about?
content:
I should start this by saying I'm not diagnosed with PTSD, but I do have a lot of trauma to work through. It affects my daily life so much that I'm often isolating myself in a dark room, because it is the only time I feel safe. I'm safest when there are no people around me.

I get the anxiety attacks, the panic attacks, the restless nights and appetite changes. I use substances. I don't take care of myself and don't eat enough. I have lost a lot of weight. The worst part is trying to socialize or being in a public place, such as my work, because I'm so overly cautious, quiet, and clumsy. There's a man whose face I can't look at, not even for a second, because his face looks so much like the person that gave me this trauma... 

Anyway, I have this really bad habit of pretending to be perfectly fine. I try to smile at people, although not so much now, since they don't like me anymore. These are people I see five days a week. They talk badly about me. I don't handle rejection well, so I break down and cry in a dark room or I keep doing my job, but I mentally space out and just go through the motions. It's a cleaning job, so I keep cleaning but get lost in my head. I have stopped looking at these people and talking to them, but they now talk about me more. I pretend not to hear it.

Unfortunately it's a very social job, and that's the thing I cannot do. I panic when I have to talk to somebody. They could ask, "Hey, how are you?" My response is *always* "Good, how are you?" It's automatic and it feels robotic, like I'm not human or something. 

I've done this for so long. It's how I survive the day, by simply smiling and saying I'm good. I don't know how to stop.

Maybe it doesn't help that this workplace isn't healthy for me. I had just started this job, not even three months in, when a trauma happened. It involved a coworker, and people talk about it but they don't know *anything.* They treat it as some little mishap, maybe a bit of an inappropriate interaction. It's no big deal to them and it happened "so long ago." Hearing stuff like that pisses me off, because it wasn't some minor thing. A coworker took advantage of me, fully. 

It's so hard to just say the words. I've gone back to avoiding my problems, whisking them into my mind while I force a smile. The place I work in now is the same as when I was traumatized. So I already know, I can't heal in this environment. Worse than that, nobody knows what happened to me so nobody understands my trauma responses. They think I'm weird, or stupid, or they avoid me. I was hurt and I have FOUGHT to be where I am now, only to hear daily smack talk about me, and not a single person there understands. One guy even wears a SI prevention jacket and still doesn't get it... he talks the most crap. 

I'm so tired of fighting. Every day is a fight. I'm not eating, sleeping, and I always want to SH. I'm making myself ill. title: I got caught doing my "PTSD check" before bed and I felt so ashamed
content:
this is a pretty long and rambly post about feeling guilt, shame, and embarrassment about my PTSD.

so every night before bed I do my "PTSD check" which is what I've begun to call (in my head) the thing I do where I going around the house making sure the doors are locked.

well tonight my mom woke up for the morning as I was about to go to bed and she caught me checking the front door (the last one I check before bed as it's the closest one to my bedroom). it was dark as I had already turned the lights off so I couldn't see her, but I heard her quietly call my name as to not wake anyone up. it scared the shit out of me. I haven't felt that scared for my life in a while; like genuine "oh fuck!" fear. I turned around and just stared across the room but it was too dark to see her. she called my name again and I said "hello?" while trying not to panic more than I already was. I could barely make out her body coming through the darkness. it wasn't till I could see her face that the fear fully eased. turns out she just wanted a hug before I went to bed. 

I felt a pretty intense need to explain what I was doing but I was overcome with shame and embarrassment. no one knows I do that every night. it's been my little secret. my shameful act of patheticness that I do every single night despite the fact that I know logically I am safe and don't need to worry so much anymore. it's my delusional anxious bullshit. my guilt to carry. yet she saw me do it. 

or at least I think she did. it might have been too dark for how to make out what I was doing. luckily she didn't see me stare out of the window for a few seconds "just to make sure" like I did just before I made sure the door was locked, which is when she called my name. but I didn't realize till writing this post that she might have just thought I was locking the door before bed, which is at least a somewhat normal behavior I think. oh well.

I hate how much shame, guilt, and embarrassment I feel about my PTSD. I feel like no one believes me; like I'm just making it up or massively exaggerating. when I do tell someone I have PTSD I almost always mention that it's diagnosed so they won't think I'm being dramatic; despite the fact that I firmly believe that self diagnosis is valid. maybe it's just not valid for me? maybe it'd only be "being dramatic" if it were me? why do I have so much guilt and self hatred because *I was abused?* what sense does that even make? how did I get here..?

.

***edit/update (kind of):***
I want to thank everyone for sending me so many nice messages and helping me see this from an outsiders perspective.

I'm sorry I'm taking so long to reply to everyone! this is a very hard subject for me to talk about so I've only been able to reply to a couple comments every few days. I promise I will get to yours tho, I'll read them all, don't worry! all the ones I have read and replied to have been very helpful and supportive and I'm sure the rest are too. thank you again and I'm sorry again for taking so long.

title: This seems minor compared to what a lot of you are going through rn, but it's tearing my sanity to pieces. Probably due to how personal it is.
content:
TW: mentions of various abuse, self-harm/suicide attempts.

Long story...very long story, and probably not one I'll bother boring anyone with, but basically, the past few years have been hard, mentally and emotionally speaking. Now, it's to the point where it's affecting my health. Sleep paralysis, blood coming from my nose, migraines, nausea...you name it.  
Anyway, for about 2 yrs now I've been pouring my heart and soul into a novel with the intent of helping myself and others heal from trauma and PTSD, or at least to know they're/we're not alone. It's been liberating at points, yes, but also ridiculously suffocating and...just...too real. It's sci-fi, and I love the genre, but it's just too damn real. My emotions are already a jumbled mess, so this project is kind of added stress even though I know I'd be failing to quit it altogether. I just need to push through harder, ig, but it's FRUSTRATING when I feel so alone with it.  
Like, I have some people who cheer me on from the surface, but there's still a huge disconnect, or so it feels. Then there are others who've ghosted me about it. Still, more who have gaslit me about it. Been judged bc of how controversial and NOT like a lot of present media is regarding certain topics. It's still the first freaking draft! ON BOOK ONE! JUST BOOK ONE! I'm stuck and fuming at this point, even though I technically know what's next.

What are the topics?  
Well....  
Two of my three MCs were abused as kids and teenagers--emotionally/mentally, physically, and sexually. Yup. And I went through similar things myself, which owes to a lot of my PTSD.  
MMC puts up walls and an aggressive front as a coping mechanism (largely what I do), and sometimes gets into self-harm and suicide attempts (I did years ago...) bc of all of the shit he's been through. FMC (friend and eventual gf) understands him and tries to prevent his...attempts in a way that's, well, empathetic and non-judging. Meanwhile, she's dealing with her own shit bc her primary abuser is back in town and working for the villain. She opens up to MMC about what happened to her, and it pisses him off badly for her sake.  
Yeah, and the MMC also grew up surrounded by a cannibalistic, satanistic (not in name, per se, but lots of similar practices) cult that treated love like a taboo and all sorts of twisted bullshit. Hard stuff.  
Anyway, this makes the project...close to home, and...controversial.

During some research, out of curiosity I looked at how various books on the market dealt with stuff like SA. At "best," (not really good, tbh) it was glossed over or flat out ignored. At worst, it was ROMANTICIZED. Like, 9 times out of 10. I found out about Haunting Adeline. Straight up disgusting frickery from hell. Like, WHAT THE HELL IS THAT STORY? WHO COULD WRITE SUCH EXPLOITATIVE AND FILTHY GARBAGE THAT IS A DIRECT AFFRONT TO ANY SA SURVIVOR? Object rape with a gun. Are you kidding me? Full-on rape for literal dozens and dozens of pages straight. Shit like this \*supposed\* "good and hot guy" saying, "your body reacted. You want this." Straight from the fucking rapist's handbook of lies!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  
And, as if that wasn't bad enough, a side character, also supposedly good and the MC's best friend, CONDONED OBVIOUS RAPE! WTF? THEN...THEN...SOMEHOW, the MC FALLS IN "LOVE" WITH THE DIPSHIT? Okay, I know there are twisted accounts of people feeling confused and having feelings, but seriously? Not like that, folks. And it SURE as hell isn't love. Love does not damage someone else's boundaries or take advantage of them.  
Anyway, after seeing such things, you might say it bolstered my drive for writing my own story. To do JUSTICE to things, or at the very least to the best of my capabilities.

Now, I'm a survivor, yes, but have had zero relationship experience in the sense of trying to navigate...things in light of it to a healing/feeling safe(ish) point. So, in order to do it right for my characters who are, I reach out in effort to get opinions from survivors who've had relationships after such abuse. Many have been quite supportive, BUT...  
I still feel alone, honestly, bc...well, I go to a different subreddit to get advice for this and I got downvoted to pieces. Like, what gives?????? I pour my LITERAL blood, sweat, and tears into this book and that's the reaction I get? Why??? I'm trying to help my own tribe here, in whatever small way. I'm pretty sure I explained things in a very sensitive and respectful way too, with the exception of slamming that damn Adeline book in order to show that I'm writing DIFFERENT from it. I mean, I get it, I knew my WIP would be super niche from the start--that's okay. What's NOT okay is feeling constantly judged, ignored, or outright battered for it when I'm already struggling enough as is just to get it onto the freaking page.  
"Your main character is a temper tantrum throwing maniac and a spineless wimp." Dude, he's been through hell and back. He has his issues, yes, but that's seriously a slight to PTSD as a whole, and he's more resilient than a lot of folks in spite of it.  
"His reasons for self-harm are stupid." Seriously? In what way? He's had his mother figure crucified in front of him, had a close friend betray him and sell him into slavery at which point he was trafficked and used as a sex toy, gaslit, beaten, branded, and loads of other shit.  
"His relationship with the FMC is repulsive." What? Why? In my and a lot of other opinions I've managed to scrape up, it's beautiful and tender.  
"He should honestly die." UUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUURGH.  
"This project was a shitstorm from the start and I've no confidence in it at all moving forward." \*angry emoji\*  
That's just a sample of the negative feedback I've gotten.

Furthermore, I'm having other issues. Possibly projection ones. I've started to question myself (my characters question themselves too about the same literal thing), "are they even allowed the intimacy they get later?" Reason tells me, "YES, OF COURSE!" etc. But like, idk how to explain it. Some of you probably get what I'm saying. Like, "okay, how is it possible for something meant to be safe and beautiful to be that after it's been so damn mangled, tainted, and butchered?" And then there's questions like, "Sexuality is gross."  
Yeah, my characters are sex-repulsed like me, but the thing is...I WANT them to be able to share intimacy with each other without feeling so bad about it. (Context, they wait to have sex until they feel ready enough for it and it happens slow with questions and reassurances and breaks throughout the, uh, process.)  
I want them to have their babies. I want them to have that kind of happiness (even though they'll be happy apart from it bc, let's face it, there's WAY more to life than just sex).

I don't give a rat's ass if I don't get that. Truly. I \*\*\*prefer/want\*\*\* to stay single, and I'm possibly asexual. But the...subject is nonetheless tainted for me too.

Anyway, I don't even know what to do at this point. Maybe this was a stupid and painful-only endeavor after all.... :(

Sorry if I sound so mad. My PTSD is also getting pressed by other things....

Only thing keeping me from blowing up even more rn is listening to Stand My Ground by Within Temptation on loop....

title: Starting a new treatment next week after years of hell
content:
I lost my younger brother when he was only 30 in 2016. Two years later I had the ptsd diagnosis while in the hospital. I tried to see a couple of therapists but I really hated it. I hated sitting there and reliving the whole thing and even worse, feeling like the therapist wasn't even listening to me. I kinda just gave up.

This really took over my life and contributed to my divorce. My ex would always tell me I needed to go back into therapy or he would be done. Whenever I would hear this from him or feel like he was angry with me, I just shut down. Sometimes I wonder if he thought I didn't care but that wasn't the case at all. I just got to such a low point that I was convinced I was a burden.

I won't have insurance for much longer now that the divorce is almost complete so I'm seeing a therapist while I can. She seems to be more knowledgeable than any of the therapists I had in the past. 

She told me that more recent research shows the traditional methods of treatment just weren't effective. She described how trauma is an automatic nervous response and we can't control it. It can also exacerbate other issues like my ADHD, which explains a lot in itself. 

She described a technique we are starting next week called trauma tapping. The gist is that trauma is activated on one side of the brain. This technique activates the amygdala and gets the other side of the brain to react so that we still have the ability of logical thought when we are exposed to a trigger. By having both sides of the brain activated instead of the side that handles trauma, we are better able to regulate ourselves and not go into a panic attack.

I've gone through the past few years believing I must be a terrible person because I can't get help. But I REALLY didn't want to see a new therapist and tell my story all over again. With this lady I haven't had to do that at all. She says research shows the old method of having patients describe the trauma in detail has turned out to actually be horrible, not helpful. 

Hearing this almost kind of woke me up. "Wait so I'm not a complete dirtbag incapable of caring? It was always a nervous system response beyond my control?" For once in a long time I'm actually eager for our session so I can see if I get results. I blame myself for contributing so much to my divorce, but now I feel like it was something I was never going to get control of until meeting the right therapist. I mean, the last therapist I had would do phone calls and I could hear him driving around while talking to me. Therapy doesn't seem like the time to have divided attention. 🤦‍♀️

Anyone else try this technique? Sorry idk if this is a rant or a post looking for advice. I just wanted to talk about this somewhere.

title: Nightmares Unrelated to the Trauma?
content:
I’ve been diagnosed with PTSD for many years.  One thing I’ve always wondered about is whether my chronic nightmares count as a symptom, because even though they happen most nights, and are always highly distressing, they have nothing to do with the trauma I experienced.  They’re usually about completely fictional things like a zombie apocalypse or hiding from monsters.  Last night’s was about a planet full of people who had to live underground because if sunlight touched them, it destroyed them in visually grotesque ways.

I’ve never heard of someone with PTSD having nightmares that weren’t just recreations of the traumatic event.  Could my nightmares still be PTSD related, or are they just a random coincidental stand-alone parasomnia that I have separate from my PTSD?

title: Not knowing what to expect is a trigger for me (TW for abuse)
content:
In working with my therapist, I've recently realized a commonality between a lot of the events that send me into tailspins and activate my fight-or-flight. Very often, the theme is that I don't know what to expect from an interaction with an individual, so my nervous system goes "harm imminent; must prepare". 

  
Usually, this comes out in instances where I'm dealing with interpersonal issues and the other person doesn't respond. Like, if I say something like "hey, there appears to be an issue between us consisting of XYZ; how can we address this and come to a resolution?" and they don't say anything in response, there is something so deeply, deeply embedded in my psyche that takes that to mean that they are readying to harm me. It's the calm before the storm, so to speak. This originates from trauma with my dad, who used to always go completely silent right before he'd >!pull out his gun !<or  >!beat the hell out of me!<. And it was always immediately following instances where I tried to advocate for myself or bring up an issue. I had a different abuser, too, who would always go completely silent before doing something awful, so that, for me, is just always there in those prolonged silences. They are terrifying, even if there is no solid reason for them to be at this point.

  
I know I can't *make* people talk to me, and I don't want to be disrespectful of anyone or their boundaries. But especially when I'm bringing up conflict or an issue with someone, I am always so afraid that they're gonna harm me when they just say nothing and stonewall (and I will call it stonewalling, since I express myself clearly, ask for a response/clarity, and am able to see that they read those messages), such that these interactions - or lack thereof - *become* traumatic, themselves. My nervous system is waiting for the blow to come, waiting to fight or run, and living in that space around these kinds of people is incredibly stressful. Please, I do not care how impolite you are in addressing me; I do not care if you dislike me or if you have some grade-A smack to talk about me. Cuss me out, yell at me, tell me you hate me with every fiber of your being, but please say *something*. 

  
Mainly, it's a situation at work/school with a colleague. I have gotten the sense since I met this person that they have just outright hated me from the start. I have tried to build a rapport with them, tried to establish some kind of connection there so that I can work with them without issue, but their cold body language/tone/facial expressions/passive aggressive little comments/scoffing/eye rolling/judgmental remarks have all persisted. I do not trust them at all because I find them incredibly unpredictable. Once in a blue moon, they'll act like we're besties and wave at me or like a bunch of my social media posts, all the while ignoring the actual attempts to address this issue. And having to work with them, as I have in the past, has led me to completely shut down and go nonverbal in their presence. I have always left those interactions early, without fail. I've brought this up multiple times, thinking *ok, maybe they just aren't aware they're coming off this way and it's all a big misunderstanding.* They've not responded to any of those attempts to address it, so I'm just increasingly distressed even being in the same room as them because I don't know what to expect. The not knowing what to expect has me in this constant state of fight-or-flight near them, so I've been avoiding them. Unfortunately, this also means avoiding many of the spaces and communities I otherwise would have loved to be part of and connected to, but I don't feel like I can safely be in those environments because all my brain can focus on is *where are they, where are the exits to this place, do not get near me, what will I do if \_\_\_\_\_* and that's exhausting; I no longer derive any joy from those communities or experiences because my body won't stop acting like there's a predator afoot.

  
Maybe they are totally harmless and it *is* all a big misunderstanding. But I wish they'd communicate that and not leave me to guess - because my guess will always be "they are going to harm me" since that is the background I have to draw on. I understand I am not owed this communication and they are not responsible for my nervous system's responses to them, but I will still continue to be terrified around them and avoid any instances where they might be till I know I am not in danger. Unfortunately, that means not going to a lot of things, which is becoming isolating. 

  
I'm not sure how to tackle this. Thoughts?

title: Exposure therapy is making things so much worse
content:
In therapy we have reached the point of touching on exposure therapy. I didn't think I needed it, because I will just go into situations even if a bit uncomfortable, it was never a big deal. I realize now that that is because I was dissociating and now, everything is unravelling in my life where I don't feel comfortable doing anything where everything has some level of more intense discomfort. 

I was the one to check out new places, interact with people, talk to the waitress or the cashier, just make a phone call to a place, go dance on the street to music with others. Addressing some issues with avoiding work related spaces and now I have realized I was dissociating through it all my whole life. It feels like everything is beginning to unravel in my life and that I am trudging through mud that keeps rising higher and higher. 

I'm now reluctant to leave my house, I'm reluctant to interact with anyone besides one person in my life. I don't want to interact, or be perceived. 

Exposure therapy work is now me actively trying to be mindful and ground myself back while then battling the slew of negative emotions and thoughts that send me into ungrounded states. I am EXHAUSTED. Life goes on so I still need to go out and do certain things but now that I am aware of how I have been interacting with the world this whole time, I feel even more alienated and strange. 

My anxiety and depression is still low overall, coming up situationaly to reasonable triggers. I still do things around the house. Most medications end up having side effects that worsen the dissociation by further emotional numbing. I'm contraindicated for anything that effects heart rate including things slowing rate heart. 

Not sure what to do or where to go from here. When I talk about all this I tend to hear "this is beyond my scope" and the like, or "what you are feeling is normal, our society is sick." The latter is great and all, but where do I go from here? I'm having a harder and harder time surviving and in trying to make things better it feels like I have opened a Pandora's box of issues.

title: How do I start believing in myself so I can move on and find joy in creative interests again?
content:
I'm autistic, so growing up I was always criticized and punished severely in school just for being myself. My self esteem was destroyed and I basically threw everything about me away so I could be an empty, depressed shell and fit in with the rest of the sheep. 

(US public schools are extremely ableist. It's like you're a square being shoved through a circular hole by force, and if you don't like it then you get punished and diagnosed with Oppositional Defiant Disorder. Special Ed here is a fucking joke.)

When I was a kid I used to really be into art, I loved drawing and I even used to win 1st place in contests sometimes. But ever since then, I was always made to feel like nothing I ever did was right or good enough and that I was forever destined to be the black sheep that didn't deserve to be happy or at peace with themselves.

So I completely gave up drawing and stopped practicing for years. Not being in school anymore as an adult didn't change that mentality.

I could've been so good by now, but instead I'm starting over from scratch and I still have so much internalized hate and shame for myself that I can't even finish a basic sketch before immediately giving up and "saving it for later"....I've never had a sketch book that wasn't just wasted paper.

If I'm not good at something right away then that ends up being a reflection of me, even though I know I shouldn't be feeling that way or expecting to be perfect on my 1st try. I'm still not used to not being "gifted" anymore.

Gaming was my escapism for a while, but creative life sim genres are my favorite (ACNH, Minecraft, anything that gives you a lot of creative freedom to express yourself), which also sends me down the social media rabbit hole of comparing my work to others and impulsively deleting my save files. Taking a break and switching to other types of games doesn't help.

I could play a game for years, have countless hours built up on my switch, and not have a single save to show for it. 

Now I'm stuck in a horrible cycle of slowly killing myself with dopamine (smoking weed, binge eating, watching brain rot to avoid thinking, phone scrolling, bedrotting) to procrastinate my greatest fear (happily expressing myself in a safe, creative environment with no one around to judge or make fun of me for it).

It doesn't make sense for me to avoid something I've always wanted, but the main issue besides the shame is just straight up not knowing who I am anymore since I turned myself into a blank slate and shut my brain off. Being blank isn't an empowering opportunity for redemption to me.

What if I finally managed to build the perfect virtual world or finish the best art project ever, just for it to still not feel "right" or "me"? What if nothing ever brings me happiness or closure and I'm stuck self loathing forever?? I also have extreme commitment issues from being forced to move all the time.

No matter how hard I try to redeem myself and succeed in life in other aspects, my creative "purpose" still proves to be the bane of my existence. Sometimes I wish I could have a free trial of death (not just closing my eyes to sleep) and see if that would be truly worse than living like this...

title: Traumatic Stress
content: # Sexual abuse is a horrific and traumatic experience that can have long-lasting effects on a survivor's life. One of the most common outcomes of sexual abuse is Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), a mental health condition that can develop after a person has been exposed to a traumatic event or series of events. PTSD can have a significant impact on a survivor's daily life, relationships, and overall well-being.Individuals who have experienced sexual abuse may struggle with intrusive thoughts, memories, and flashbacks of the traumatic event. These symptoms can be triggered by various stimuli, such as physical touch, certain smells, or situations that remind the survivor of the abuse. As a result, survivors may experience heightened levels of anxiety, fear, and distress, making it difficult for them to feel safe and secure in their [surroundings.In](http://surroundings.In) addition to intrusive thoughts and memories, survivors of sexual abuse may also experience emotional numbness, avoidance behaviors, and hypervigilance. Emotional numbness can manifest as a disconnection from one's emotions and difficulty expressing feelings or forming attachments with others. Avoidance behaviors may involve avoiding certain places, people, or activities that remind the survivor of the abuse. Hypervigilance is a state of increased arousal and alertness, where the survivor is constantly on edge and scanning their environment for potential threats. Furthermore, sexual abuse can impact a survivor's relationships with others, including family members, friends, and romantic partners. Survivors may struggle with trust issues, intimacy challenges, and difficulties in forming and maintaining healthy relationships. They may also experience feelings of shame, guilt, and self-blame, which can contribute to a sense of isolation and loneliness.It is important for survivors of sexual abuse to seek help and support from mental health professionals, such as therapists, counselors, and support groups. Therapy can help survivors process their trauma, develop coping strategies, and learn how to manage their symptoms of PTSD. Medication may also be prescribed to help manage symptoms of anxiety, depression, and sleep disturbances.In conclusion, sexual abuse can have a profound impact on a survivor's life, leading to symptoms of PTSD and other mental health challenges. It is crucial for survivors to seek help and support in order to heal from their trauma and regain a sense of safety and well-being. With proper treatment and support, survivors can learn to cope with their symptoms and move forward in their recovery journey. [ ](https://www.my-story.vip/)
